citation.article-title: Clostridium uliginosum sp. nov., a novel acid-tolerant, anaerobic bacterium with connecting filaments.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Clostridium uliginosum sp. nov.
Clostridium uliginosum (u.li.gi.no'sum. L. n. uligo -inis moisture of the soil, swamp; L. neut. adj. uliginosum swampy)
Cells are rods, 8x1 μm, motile, have two to four peritrichous flagella per cell, are spore-forming, lack an outer membrane and stain Gram-negative.
Cultures contain single cells and cell chains; cells are linked by a connecting filament that is composed of a core and an outer sheath.
Anaerobe with a chemo-organotrophic, fermentative metabolism.
Grows on glucose, cellobiose, sucrose, xylose, mannose, mannitol and peptone.
Glucose is fermented to acetate, butyrate, lactate, H2 and CO2 ; with other sugars, formate is also formed.
Does not grow on lactose, maltose, glycerol, rabinose, raffinose, Casamino acids, H2/CO2, CO/CO2, vanillate or various purines or pyrimidines.
Does not carry out dissimilatory reduction of nitrate or sulfate.
Grows at 10-30 °C, with an optimum at 20-25°C.
Grows at pH 4.0-9.0, with an optimum at pH 6.5.
At 20 °C, doubling times are 6, 4 and 7 h at pH 4.0, 6.5 and 8.0, respectively.
Phylogenetically most closely related to Clostridium botulinum (types B, E and F), Clostridium acetobutylicum and other saccharolytic clostridia.
The type strain, CK55T (=DSM 12992T=ATCC BAA-53T), was isolated from an acidic forest bog.
